description: On March 17th, the government of Mali announced that schools will be closed for 3 weeks, starting on March 19th. On April 8th, the closure has been extended until May 9th. UPDATE: The original closure of school was set to last for three weeks until April 9, it has been extended on April 8 by the government to May 9 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description: On March 17th, the government of Mali announced that schools will be closed for 3 weeks, starting on March 19th. UPDATE: In Mali, schools - originally closed from March 19 - reopened on June 2 for university students and final year students who face final exams. The partial resumption of classes was boycotted by public sector teachers over fears of inadequate protection against Covid-19.

description: On March 25th, in a televised address, President Keita 'announced the implementation of a nationwide curfew between 21:00 and 05:00 (local time) as of Friday, March 27, that will remain in place until further notice'. The national police is responsible for controlling the compliance with the curfew.
On March 25 2020, President of Mali, Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, declared a state of health emergency.
On March 17th, Mali bans all commercial flights from unspecified countries affected by the coronavirus, with the exception of cargo flights, effective on March 19th 2020.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Malian President Keiga announced on March 25th that the border will be closed, except for freight and cargo shipping, effective immediately.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On March 17th, Mali bans all commercial flights from unspecified countries affected by the coronavirus, with the exception of cargo flights, effective on March 19th 2020. UPDATE: Reopening of air borders as of 25 June 2020 at 00:00. New hygiene measurements for people entering the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "Mali will indefinitely suspend flights from countries affected by coronavirus in a bid to control a possible outbreak of the pandemic there, the government said Tuesday. Exception from the suspension that begins Thursday will be given to cargo flights."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 12, Mali announces that all passengers arriving in Mali via land and air will be subject to temperature testing.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Mali: The mission of the Applied Molecular Biology Laboratory (Laboratoire de Biologie Moléculaire Appliquée LBMA) "is to use its platform to provide within three hours the diagnosis of suspected cases of zoonoses such as COVID19 by the real-time PCR method. [...] The LBMA is part of: Mali's "One Health" platform; the National Institute of Public Health's (INSP) COVID19 algorithm for the management of suspected cases of disease."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Any passenger entering the country by airplaine needs to: 
- Complete the declaration of health form
-  present a negative COVID-19 test certificate not more than three days old
- failing this, the passenger will be subjected to the COVID-19 test at the airport and must comply with the following health control measures - notwithstanding the presentation of the negative certificate, in the presence of a symptom of COVID-19, the passenger will be isolated and subjected to the screening test.
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Following the reopening of its air borders on 25 July 2020, barrier measures must be respected in the airport area and it is mandatory to present a certificate attesting to the negative status of any passenger arriving in or departing from Mali. This test is carried out only by the National Institute of Public Health.
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Mali is enforcing health monitoring on comers to Mali. it imposed a coronavirus disease surveillance form on entry points in the country for all those who enter Mali to fill in to be able to track virus circulation and any suspicious health symptoms which could be covid19 related.  it takes effect on June 18 2021, and has no specific end date up until the day this policy is being coded.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 10th, Mali's president Keita announced the 'un malien, un masque' policy, in which he announces ordering 20 million masks for the region of Bamako.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
During a visit from the Minister of Health (27th may 2020), the Governor of Timbuktu confirmed that the 130 million CFA Franc of government aid had been received and distributed according to a distribution key, namely 50 million for the regional health directorate and 80 million for the treatment centre. In-kind contributions have been received from partners engaged in the fight against Covid-19 in Timbuktu Region.

On the issue of staff shortages, the Minister pointed out that soon the department's director of human resources will make doctors and nurses available to Timbuktu's health care. Equipment will also be reinforced and the head of the department promised to equip at least one of the northern regions with a mobile laboratory to detect the disease in time for treatment instead of referring each time to Bamako.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: A meeting is initiated by the President of the Republic with all stakeholders in the issue of health, including "l´ordre des médecins du Mali" and users, in order to accelerate the implementation of the modernization plan for all hospitals in Bamako.
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: on march 12, Mali announces that all incoming passengers from countries with more than 500 cases who show major symptoms and fever superior to 37.5 degrees C will be taken to a medical facility to be tested.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Mali, the national parliamentary elections on March 29 2020 (1st round) were maintained, a day after the country's first coronavirus death. The second round was hold on April 19, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: A government´s decision to maintain certain events such as elections despite the risk of spreading the Corona virus

description: April 10, 2020 "Malian President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita has announced a coronavirus aid package [worth some 500 billion CFA francs (USD 832 million)] for poor people and hard-hit firms, as cases continue to rise in the war-torn West African state. [...] the government would shoulder water and electricity bills for the poorest people in April and May, among other measures. [...] The government would also distribute 56,000 tonnes of grain in food aid and 16,000 tonnes of animal feed, he added, and allow tax rebates for firms hit hard by the virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: A political measure providing financial aid, distributing food etc. to population groups
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Mali, every passenger arriving into the country will be receiving health and hygiene government recommendations and the 'green number' to call for information.

Since 7 July and for a period of two months, the Civil Affairs Division of MINUSMA has been implementing a "Citizen Mobilization for Zero Coronavirus in Mali" project, in collaboration with Junior Chamber International (JCI) and the Coalition of Alternative Debts of Mali (CAD-MALI). This project, which concerns Bamako and several regions of Mali, aims to support the fight against coronavirus by involving civil society actors.

Through its important communication component, nearly five million people will be indirectly reached by the awareness messages, thanks in particular to community radio stations, public notices in six languages, loudspeakers in public places, social networks and through the distribution of handwashing kits.

In addition to the six communes of the District of Bamako, activities have already taken place in Mopti, Bandiagara, Djenné, Ségou and Gao. They will continue until the end of August in Timbuktu, Kidal, Ménaka, Taoudéni, Douentza and Tessalit.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March12, Mali is enforcing a 14 day self quarantine on all passengers coming from a corona afflicted country if they have a temperature superior to 37.5 degrees celsius or show other minor symptoms. "Travelers with major symtoms will be transported to an isolation site"
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On april 10th, Mali's ministry of health formally bans all commercialization of chloroquine phosphate and discourages the consumption of the product, which does not meet certain pharmaceutical norms yet is confused with chloroquine which is thought to help fight to virus. The ministry encourages the cooperation of importers, sellers, and consumers. Any person found in possession of this medicine will be subject to legal consequences.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Other Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: Mali closes all bars and clubs on March 17th, effective on March 19th until further notice.

description: On March 30th, Mali announced reduced work hours to 7h30 to 2pm without any breaks, effective wednesday april 1st. This policy takes end on 1 August 2020:  Normal working hours shall be re-established throughout the national territory.The alternation of working days shall be discontinued. UPDATE: Normal working hours shall be re-established throughout the national territory of Mali with effect from 1 August 2020. The alternation of working days shall be discontinued.

On March 12th Mali suspends all important gatherings until further notice, such as festivals, concerts, conferences, etc. No specified cap in how many people can gather at once.

Mali on March 17th, limits all gatherings to 50 people maximum in accordance with hygiene rules, and includes cultural and political events, weddings, funerals, sporting events, etc. All public gatherings are banned. UPDATE: Gatherings were limited to 50 and include now funerals, weddings, sporting events, cultural assemblies, and political events.
